channel.title: NYT > Arts > Music
channel.copyright: Copyright 2019 The New York Times Company

item.title: The Disastrous Woodstock 50: What Went Wrong?
item.description: An announcement with no tickets. Four permit requests rejected by one small town. How the event celebrating the anniversary of a landmark rock festival crumbled.
item.dc:creator: Ben Sisario
item.media:description: Michael Lang, right, at a board hearing in Vernon, N.Y., where he hoped to move Woodstock 50.

item.title: Sleater-Kinney Asked St. Vincent for a Creative Spark. The Trio Blew Up.
item.description: After two and a half decades, the acclaimed band ventures into a different sound on its ninth album, “The Center Won’t Hold” — and moves onward without its longtime drummer.
item.dc:creator: Melena Ryzik
item.media:credit: Rozette Rago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Corin Tucker and Carrie Brownstein, Sleater-Kinney’s founding duo, on the cusp of releasing the band’s ninth album, “The Center Won’t Hold.”

item.title: Abdullah Ibrahim: A Lifetime of Dreams and Resistance at the Piano
item.description: The South African musician formed the Jazz Epistles and got a boost from Duke Ellington. Now 84, he is a Jazz Master and still a vital force onstage.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: The pianist Abdullah Ibrahim released “The Balance” earlier this year, featuring songs from his vast catalog.

item.title: Hundreds of New Concertos Bring the World to the Concert Hall
item.description: Dai Fujikura’s new work for shamisen, a three-stringed, fretless Japanese lute, premieres on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Ebright

item.title: ASAP Rocky Claims Self-Defense in Swedish Assault Trial
item.description: The rapper, whose case has drawn the attention of President Trump, said the man he threw and punched had started to attack his group.
item.dc:creator: Christina Anderson
item.media:description: Renee Black, ASAP Rocky’s mother, leaving the courthouse in Stockholm during a break in testimony on Thursday.

item.title: 12 Pop, Rock and Jazz Concerts to Check Out in N.Y.C. This Weekend
item.description: Our guide to pop and rock shows and the best of live jazz happening this weekend and in the week ahead.
item.media:description: Florist, led by Emily Sprague, above, will be at Baby’s All Right on Saturday night.

item.title: Divorced. Beheaded. Broadway.
item.description: “Six,” a British pop musical about the guess-how-many wives of Henry VIII, will open early next year.
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson
item.media:description: The first North American production of “Six” is now running at the Chicago Shakespeare Theater, and will make stops in Massachusetts, Alberta and Minnesota before arriving on Broadway early next year.

item.title: Ras G, 40, Hip-Hop Producer and Force in L.A. Music Scene, Dies
item.description: The experimental, kaleidoscopic beats he made and called “ghetto sci-fi” channeled a wide spectrum of black musical history.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello

item.title: Lebanese Band’s Concert Is Canceled After It’s Accused of Blasphemy
item.description: Critics denounced Mashrou’ Leila, and a festival canceled an upcoming concert by the group, raising concerns about freedom of expression in the relatively moderate, multi-sectarian country.
item.dc:creator: Nada Rashwan
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Woodstock 50 Is Canceled: ‘We Just Ran Out of Time’
item.description: The majority of the anniversary festival’s performers abandoned the event once its promoters tried to move it to Maryland.
item.dc:creator: Ben Sisario
item.media:description: Michael Lang, left, with John Fogerty at an event announcing Woodstock 50 in March.

item.title: Irish Band Channels the Spirit of Punk, and James Joyce
item.description: Fontaines D.C. is a breakout Irish rock act. The emphasis is on the Irish.
item.dc:creator: Amos Barshad
item.media:credit: Paulo Nunes dos Santos for The New York Times
item.media:description: From left: Carlos O’Connell, Conor Curley, Conor Deegan, Grian Chatten and Tom Coll make up the Irish rock band Fontaines D.C.

item.title: Katy Perry’s Copyright Case May Sound Familiar to These Stars
item.description: The “Dark Horse” decision is the latest in a long line of disputes that have shaped the way copyright law is handled in the music industry.
item.dc:creator: Nancy Coleman
item.media:description: Katy Perry performing “Dark Horse” at the 2014 Grammy Awards. On Monday, a federal jury said that the song improperly copied parts of a song by a Christian rap artist.

item.title: Elvis Presley Needed a Reboot in July 1969. So Did Las Vegas.
item.description: Elvis’s bona fides were in question when he returned to the stage after more than eight years. His ’69 comeback show was a make-or-break gamble.
item.dc:creator: Richard Zoglin
item.media:description: For his 1969 comeback show in Las Vegas, Elvis Presley was at his peak as a stage performer.

item.title: ASAP Rocky Trial Begins in Sweden, With a Special Envoy From America
item.description: President Trump, who has helped turn the rapper’s assault case into an international incident, sent a hostage-crisis diplomat to the courtroom.
item.dc:creator: Christina Anderson and Alex Marshall
item.media:credit: Dimitrios Kambouris/Getty Images for Diamond Ball
item.media:description: Rocky at a charity gala in New York in 2018. The rapper has been detained in Sweden since July 5.

item.title: What We Know as ASAP Rocky’s Trial Begins
item.description: The rapper pleaded not guilty to an assault charge before a court in Sweden. The case has snowballed into an international incident.
item.dc:creator: Nancy Coleman
item.media:description: ASAP Rocky, whose trial begins Tuesday.

item.title: Katy Perry Loses Copyright Battle Over ‘Dark Horse’
item.description: A jury found that the singer’s 2013 hit copied elements of a 2008 Christian rap song called “Joyful Noise.”
item.dc:creator: Ben Sisario
item.media:description: A nine-person jury returned a unanimous verdict that Katy Perry’s “Dark Horse” had infringed the copyright of a song by the artist Flame.

item.title: Lil Nas X’s ‘Old Town Road’ Breaks Billboard’s Singles Record
item.description: The “country-trap” track notched a 17th week at the top of the Hot 100, becoming the chart’s longest-running No. 1 song.
item.dc:creator: Ben Sisario
item.media:description: Lil Nas X’s “Old Town Road” came to wide attention when it was removed from a Billboard country chart. Now it holds an all-time record on the all-genre chart.

item.title: Tyler, the Creator, Funkmaster Flex and the Wildest Interview of the Year
item.description: Two hip-hop figures from different scenes and generations find that they have much more in common than not.
item.dc:creator: Jon Caramanica

item.title: Chance the Rapper’s Odes to Joy
item.description: On “The Big Day,” the 26-year-old musician attempts to convey the jubilation of married life. It’s his least effective release to date.
item.dc:creator: Jon Caramanica
item.media:description: Chance the Rapper’s recent marriage provides the bulk of the lyrical inspiration on his fourth release, “The Big Day.”

item.title: Herbie Hancock Is Still Breaking Rules
item.description: The 79-year-old pianist and composer talks about admiring Kendrick Lamar, making a new album, and calling jazz an international — not just an American — music.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times

item.title: M. Owen Lee (Father Lee to His Met Opera Radio Fans) Dies at 89
item.description: A Roman Catholic priest whose avocation for 23 years was offering commentaries and quiz answers in broadcasts during intermissions.
item.dc:creator: James Barron
item.media:credit: Keith Beaty/Toronto Star, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The Rev. M. Owen Lee as he was heading to see a favorite movie in Toronto in 1979. He wrote more than 20 books, two of them on movies. Another is called “Father Lee’s Opera Quiz Book.”

item.title: ‘Till’ Brings a Tragedy to Life
item.description: The New York Music Festival production tells the story of the summer when Emmett Till was murdered.
item.dc:creator: Laura Collins-Hughes
item.media:description: From left, Denielle Marie Gray, Tyla Collier, Taylor A. Blackman, Dwelvan David, Devin L. Roberts and Judith Franklin in “Till.”

item.title: Review: A New ‘Tannhäuser’ Brings Burger King to Bayreuth
item.description: With a drag queen and lowbrow pop culture, a rambunctious production transports Wagner’s opera to the present.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Barone
item.media:description: Stephen Gould, left, as the title character in Wagner’s “Tannhäuser,” with Elena Zhidkova and Manni Laudenbach in a new production at the Bayreuth Festival.

item.title: The Playlist: The Unstoppable ‘Old Town Road,’ and 11 More New Songs
item.description: Hear tracks by King Princess, Rick Ross and Drake, Four Tet and others.
item.dc:creator: Jon Pareles, Jon Caramanica and Giovanni Russonello
item.media:description: Yet another “Old Town Road” remix has arrived to help push Lil Nas X’s song past a Billboard chart record.

item.title: How Many Streams Is a T-Shirt Worth? Breaking Down Chart Dilemmas.
item.description: There’s more data about music consumption than ever before. That doesn’t mean we understand who’s the most popular.

item.title: The Mostly Mozart Festival, Without Mozart
item.description: Lincoln Center’s summer festival shows its newfound variety, with five programs in two days and no music by its headliner.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Tommasini
item.category: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times
item.media:description: The cellist Kian Soltani, who appeared with the pianist Julio Elizalde in a late-night concert as part of Lincoln Center’s Mostly Mozart Festival.

item.title: Blue Note Records at 80: Can a Symbol of Jazz’s Past Help Shape Its Future?
item.description: The genre is in a state of diffusion and streaming dominates listening habits. But Blue Note is still dedicated to influencing the music’s path forward.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello
item.media:description: Some stars who defined Blue Note Records years ago, from left: Lee Morgan, Herbie Hancock, Art Blakey, John Coltrane and Wayne Shorter.

item.title: A History of Blue Note Records in 15 Albums
item.description: The most storied label in jazz turns 80 this year. Hear the music that shaped its legacy.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello
item.media:description: Herbie Hancock, Bobbi Humphrey, Cecil Taylor and more: Blue Note Records has been celebrating its eight-decade history this year.

item.title: Meet the ‘Orchestra of the Street’ Bringing Classical Music to Rio’s Favelas
item.description: In a city known for samba, “nobody expects a black, poor woman to play the violin.”
item.dc:creator: Walter Thompson-Hernández
item.media:description: Orquestra de Rua in Rio de Janeiro.

item.title: Review: ‘Moulin Rouge! The Musical’ Offers a Party, and a Playlist, for the Ages
item.description: Forbidden pleasures abound in this spectacular musical, starring a dazzling Karen Olivo as a doomed Parisian chanteuse.
item.dc:creator: Ben Brantley
item.media:description: Aaron Tveit as Christian and Karen Olivo as Satine in “Moulin Rouge! The Musical” at the Al Hirschfeld Theater.

item.title: Ben Johnston, Who Made Microtonal Music Melodic, Dies at 93
item.description: Mr. Johnston’s compositions had complex theoretical underpinnings but were also, a former student said, “grounded in the real world.”
item.dc:creator: Allan Kozinn
item.media:credit: William Gedney, via David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University
item.media:description: The composer Ben Johnston at his home in Illinois in the 1960s. He created a large and varied catalog of chamber works, stage pieces and music for orchestra, choir, voice and solo piano.
